docs.text: Updated Date: JUN 23, 2021 Author: Jun ZHU To Dr. Stone: 6月23日，nature上发表一篇文章称已有大量行星或能观测地球穿过太阳，原标题是——新研究表明：地球可能已被外星系观察好多年了。小编第一时间是在B站China Daily下看到这个报道，颇有兴趣遂成此文: title 过去，现在及未来可以看到地球凌日的行星 abstrct 在探索宇宙生命可能的过程中，正在穿过恒星的系外行星(transiting exoplanet)是我们最好的研究目标。随着大孔径望远镜的出现，我们已经检测到了数以千计这样的行星，研究也迈入一个新的纪元，即在这类行星的大气层中寻找生命迹象。前人的工作已经勘察了可以看到地球掠过太阳的区域。但这些研究只考虑了恒星目前的位置，并未考虑它们的最优观测位置随着时间在不断变化。作者在他的文章中共发现了1715个离太阳100个秒差距（太阳系外天体距离单位，1个秒差距约为3.26光年）的恒星自人类早期文明伊始（约5000年前）就处在观测凌日地球的合适位置 ，另外还有319个恒星将在下一个5000年到来之前到达各自的最佳观测点。在这些恒星中有7个我们已知的系外宿主恒星，例如Ross-128，Teegarden的恒星以及Trappist-1。作者还发现人造无线电波已经扫过了这些恒星中75个最近的恒星。 Summary 展开介绍之前，我们先来认识一下什么是天文学中的凌日(transit)现象，以及为什么研究凌日现象如此重要。根据NASA的解释，凌日指行星穿过观测者和恒星的行为。太阳系内典型的凌日有金星凌日和水星凌日。 值得一提的是，大部分已知的行星都是通过“凌日法“发现的。被掩恒星的亮度数据相当重要，因为它可以确定大量的系外行星特征，例如，行星轨道大小（由凌日持续时间确定）和行星尺寸（由被掩恒星的亮度衰减确定）。最重要的一点是，我们可以研究凌日行星的大气。因为凌日过程中不同的大气成分将直接影响我们接收到光的频散，而大气成分是我们判断行星宜居性的重要因素之一。进一步我们还可以通过计算行星轨道大小和恒星温度来评估宜居性。 Reference: previous, present and future ETZ. docs.text: Updated Date: JUN 28, 2021 How to load big data (> 4 Gb) in Deep Learning ? Why DO NOT use pickle or numpy for big data size ? Please See here Tensorflow What is data pipeline ? A pipeline is a series of algorithms chained, composed, and scrambled together in some ways to process a stream of data, it has inputs and it yields outputs. The purpose of data pipelines: A lot of data preprocessing needs to be done to create input data for the ML algorithm or to load data into GPU for training. Similarly, the output is just some number in softwarem which will need to be processed to perform some action in the real world. The "ETL" principle for data pipelines 1. Extract 2. transform 3. load: load our dataset into the appropriate device such as a GPU or TPU. ![tf.FIFOQueue](https://www.tensorflow.org/images/IncremeterFifoQueue.gif) ```python ##=======================================================## ## data loader reads data from disk ====================## ## fills the queue and yields mini-batch of desried size=## ##=======================================================## class ThreadRunner(object): """ This class manages the queuing and dequeuing. """ def __init__(self): self.feat = tf.placeholder(dtype=tf.float32, shape=[None,25,25]) self.labels = tf.placeholder(dtype=tf.int32, shape=[None,]) self.name = tf.placeholder(dtype=tf.string, shape=[None,]) # queue defined using tensorflow holds the fetaures and labels equal to capacity defined self.queue = tf.RandomShuffleQueue(shapes=[[25,25],[25,25],[]], dtypes=[tf.float32,tf.int32,tf.string], capacity=1384, min_after_dequeue=1000) # filling queue using enqueue_many operations self.enqueue_op = self.queue.enqueue_many([self.feat,self.labels,self.name]) # capacity: An integer. The upper bound on the number of elements that may be stored in this queue. def get_inputs(self): """ Return's tensors containing a batch of feature sets and labels of size 32 """ features, labels, name = self.queue.dequeue_many(32) return features, labels, name def thread_main(self, sess): """ Function run on alternate thread. Basically, keep adding data to the queue. """ for features, labels, name in data_iterator(): sess.run(self.enqueue_op, feed_dict={self.feat:features,self.labels:labels, self.name:name}) def start_threads(self, sess, n_threads=2): """ Start background threads to feed queue """ threads = [] for n in range(n_threads): sys.stdout.flush()#force to print buffer "thread started :", n t = threading.Thread(target=self.thread_main, args=(sess,)) t.daemon = True # thread will close when parent quits t.start() threads.append(t) return threads ##=======================================================## ## restricts the queuing process to cpu==================## ##=======================================================## with tf.device("/cpu:0"): run_thread = ThreadRunner() features, labels, name = run_thread.get_inputs() ##=======================================================## ## initiating the session and starting threads===========## ##=======================================================## sess = tf.Session() tf.train.start_queue_runners(sess=sess) custom_runner.start_threads(sess) print "thread started :" ##=======================================================## ## to load the data simply run sess as below=============## ##=======================================================## feat_X, Y = sess.run([features, labels, name]) ##=======================================================## ## call optimizer to run on mini-batch===================## ##=======================================================## sess.run([train_opt], feed_dict = {X: feat_X, Y: Y}) the QueueBase class in tensorflow x = tf.queue.QueueBase(dtypes, shapes, names, queue_ref) x.close() x.dequeue() x.dequeue_many(n) # If the queue is closed and there are less than n elements left, # then an OutOfRange exception is raised. x.enqueue(vals) # At runtime, this operation may raise an error if the queue is # tf.QueueBase.close before or during its execution. x.enqueue_many(vals) @staticmethod from_list(index, queues) # Create a queue using the queue reference from queues[index]. x.is_closed() x.size() some Derived Queue class in tensorflow tf.queue.FIFOQueue(capacity, dtypes) tf.queue.RandomShuffleQueue(capacity, min_after_dequeue, dtypes) tf.queue.PaddingFIFOQueue(capacity, dtypes, shapes) tf.queue.PriorityQueue(capacity, dtypes) fit() and fit_generator() in Keras For any deep learning experiment the training involves updating the model weights by estimating the gradients of loss function. To quickly iterate through the data requires how fast the mini-batches can be fetched and run on GPU for loss and gradient computation. Numpy offers the functionality to read the data from disk without loading into RAM (a scikit-learn way). Note: Avoid loading the data into RAM and read data from disk on an iteration basis. However when using this iterator with Keras .fit_generator queues the mini-batches for seamless training without requiring an optimizer to wait for next batch fit() is much similar to sklearn's fit method, where you pass array of features as x values and target as y values. You pass your whole dataset at once in fit method. Also, use it if you can load whole data into your memory (small dataset) . In fit_generator(), you don't pass the x and y directly, instead they come from a generator. As it is written in keras documentation, generator is used when you want to avoid duplicate data when using multiprocessing. This is for practical purpose, when you have large dataset . How to write a generator for Keras ? 'keras script' import numpy as np from keras.models import Sequential from my_classes import DataGenerator # Parameters params = {'dim': (32,32,32), 'batch_size': 64, 'n_classes': 6, 'n_channels': 1, 'shuffle': True} # Datasets partition = # IDs labels = # Labels # Generators training_generator = DataGenerator(partition['train'], labels, **params) validation_generator = DataGenerator(partition['validation'], labels, **params) # Design model model = Sequential() [...] # Architecture model.compile() # Train model on dataset model.fit_generator(generator=training_generator, validation_data=validation_generator, use_multiprocessing=True, workers=6) 'a data generator for keras' import numpy as np import keras class DataGenerator(keras.utils.Sequence): 'Generates data for Keras' def __init__(self, list_IDs, labels, batch_size=32, dim=(32,32,32), n_channels=1, n_classes=10, shuffle=True): 'Initialization' self.dim = dim self.batch_size = batch_size self.labels = labels self.list_IDs = list_IDs self.n_channels = n_channels self.n_classes = n_classes self.shuffle = shuffle self.on_epoch_end() def __len__(self): 'Denotes the number of batches per epoch' return int(np.floor(len(self.list_IDs) / self.batch_size)) def __getitem__(self, index): 'Generate one batch of data' # Generate indexes of the batch indexes = self.indexes[index*self.batch_size:(index+1)*self.batch_size] # Find list of IDs list_IDs_temp = [self.list_IDs[k] for k in indexes] # Generate data X, y = self.__data_generation(list_IDs_temp) return X, y def on_epoch_end(self): 'Updates indexes after each epoch' self.indexes = np.arange(len(self.list_IDs)) if self.shuffle == True: np.random.shuffle(self.indexes) def __data_generation(self, list_IDs_temp): 'Generates data containing batch_size samples' # X : (n_samples, *dim, n_channels) # Initialization X = np.empty((self.batch_size, *self.dim, self.n_channels)) y = np.empty((self.batch_size), dtype=int) # Generate data for i, ID in enumerate(list_IDs_temp): # Store sample X[i,] = np.load('data/' + ID + '.npy') # Store class y[i] = self.labels[ID] return X, keras.utils.to_categorical(y, num_classes=self.n_classes) Reference: Input pipeline for deep learning experiments in Keras, Tensorflow and Pytorch what is queue ? docs.text: For any deep learning experiment the training involves updating the model weights by estimating the gradients of loss function. To quickly iterate through the data requires how fast the mini-batches can be fetched and run on GPU for loss and gradient computation. Numpy offers the functionality to read the data from disk without loading into RAM (a scikit-learn way). Note: Avoid loading the data into RAM and read data from disk on an iteration basis. However when using this iterator with Keras .fit_generator queues the mini-batches for seamless training without requiring an optimizer to wait for next batch fit() is much similar to sklearn's fit method, where you pass array of features as x values and target as y values. You pass your whole dataset at once in fit method. Also, use it if you can load whole data into your memory (small dataset) . In fit_generator(), you don't pass the x and y directly, instead they come from a generator. As it is written in keras documentation, generator is used when you want to avoid duplicate data when using multiprocessing. This is for practical purpose, when you have large dataset .

Overview build the Graph, it represents the data flow of the computers run the session, it executes the operations in the Graph Flexibility When you create a graph, you are not bound to run the whole graph and can control the parts of the graph that are executed separately. This provides a huge flexibility with your models. Session To compute anything, a graph must be launched in a session. Technically, session places the graph ops (operations) on hardware such as CPUs or GPUs and provides methods to execute them. sess = tf.Session() print(sess.run(c)) sess.close() Or you can use with tf.Session() as sess , instead with tf.Session() as sess: print(sess.run(c)) The difference between Python-name and TensorFlow-name. Can be substituted with tf.constant() for creating the input variables as Tensors instead of simply using Python variables. A More complicated example import tensorflow as tf x = 2 y = 3 add_op = tf.add(x, y, name='Add') mul_op = tf.multiply(x, y, name='Multiply') pow_op = tf.pow(add_op, mul_op, name='Power') useless_op = tf.multiply(x, add_op, name='Useless') with tf.Session() as sess: pow_out, useless_out = sess.run([pow_op, useless_op]) Reference easy tensorflow

docs.text: Updated Date: JUN 23, 2021 Faults and Rock Rheology Elastic, viscous and plastic behavior in the Earth's interior Terminology Rheology: the study of the flow of the matter, primarily in a liquid or gas state, but also as "soft solids" or solids under conditions in which they respond with plastic flow rather than deforming elastically in response to applied force. Newtonian fluid: a fluid in which the viscous stresses arising from its flow, at every point, are linearly correlated to the local strain rate --the rate of change of its deformation over time. That is equivalent to saying those forces are proportional to the rates of change of the fluids's velocity vector as one moves away from the point in question in various directions. dextral: on the right side or the right hand. For sinistral, vice versa. Rock failure and faults rocks are brittle at atmosphere pressure and room temperature elastic behavior until faults forms faults are introduced when the shear stress is larger than the yield stress. The yield stress increases with the normal stress (Byerlee's law) . Fault types Normal faults: \(\sigma_{yy}=\rho gy, \sigma_{xx}=\rho gy +\Delta \sigma_{xx}, \sigma_{zz}=\rho gy +\nu \Delta \sigma_{xx}\) (due to \(\epsilon_{zz}=0\) ), where \(\sigma_{xx}\lt0\) Thrust faults: the same as Normal fault, but \(\sigma_{xx}>0\) strike-slip faults: Byerlee's law It concerns the shear stress required to slide one rock over another . The rocks have macroscopically flat surfaces, but the surfaces have small asperities that make them "rough". For a given experiment and at normal stresses \(\sigma_n\) below about 2000 bars (200 Mpa) the shear stress increases approximately linearly with the normal stress ( \(\tau=0.85\sigma_n\) ) and is highly dependent on rock type and the character (roughness) of the surfaces. Byerlee's law states that with increased normal stress the required shear stress continues to increase, but the rate of increase decreases ( \(\tau=0.5+0.6\sigma_n\) ) , and becomes nearly independent of rock type . Mohr-coulomb yielding criterion \(\tau=\sigma \tan (\phi)+c\) \(\phi\) is called the angle of internal friction, it's a intrinsic property of the rocks \(c\) is cohesion For wet rock with a pore pressure (neglecting cohesion), \(|\tau|=f_s(\sigma_n-p_w)\) In the context of hydraulic fracturing in shale gas mining, defining an effective coefficient of friction . Anderson's theory of faulting Anderson recognized that since the principal stress directions are directions of zero shear stress, we can place faults in the context of principal stress. All faults have a common function, to extend the crust in one direction and shorten it in another. The directions of shortening and stretching are at right angles to one another. For a thrust faulting (assumed with dip angle \(\beta\) ), we get \(\Delta \sigma_{xx}\propto \frac{1}{\pm \sin(2\theta)-f_s(1+cos(2\theta))}\) , where \(\theta=\pi/2-\beta\) . Faulting will occur at angles that minimize \(|\Delta \sigma_{xx}|\) , so \(\tan(2\beta) = \pm \frac{1}{f_s}\) & \(\Delta \sigma_{xx}=\frac{\pm 2f_s(\rho gy-p_w)}{(1+f_s^2)^{1/2}\mp f_s}\) Evidence of the viscous layering in the Earth's mantle long-wavelength geoid anomalies mantle convection wavelength inversion from post-glacial rebound : good for two-layer model, trade-off for four-layer model

docs.text: Updated Date: JUN 23, 2021 Geodynamics in 2021 spring, lectured by Prof. Leng terminology Geodynamics: a subfield of geophysics dealing with dynamics of the Earth. It applies physics, chemistry and mathematics to the understanding of how mantle convection leads to plate tectonics and geologic phenomena such as seafloor spreading, mountain building, volcanoes, earthquakes, faulting and so on. overview Geodynamics is generally concerned with processes that move materials throughout the Earth. In the Earth's interior, movement happens when rocks melt or deform and flow in response to a stress field. deformation of rocks elastic: < yield strength & << relaxation time The magnitude of the stress cannot exceed the yield strength of a material, and the time scale of the stress cannot approach the relaxation time of the material . If stress exceeds the yield strength of a material, bonds begin to break, which can lead to ductile or brittle deformation. ductile: > yield strength & = relaxation time Ductile deformation happens when the temperature of a system is high enough so that a significant fraction of the material microstates are unbound. Examples include bending of the lithosphere under volcanic islands or sedimentary basins, and bending at oceanic trenches. brittle: > yield strength & < relaxation time When strain localizes faster than these relaxation processes can redistribute it , brittle deformation occurs. Thermodynamics The most important thermodynamic variables are temperature and pressure. Within the upper lithosphere, brittle deformation is common. After the brittle-ductile transition zone, ductile deformation becomes dominant . Forces The main motive force behind stress in the Earth is provided by the energy from radioisotope decay, friction, and residual heat . Negative thermal buoyancy of the oceanic plates is the primary cause of subduction and plate tectonics, while positive thermal buoyancy may lead to mantle plumes, which could explain intraplate volcanism . Methods Data includes field observations, geodesy, radiometric dating, petrology, mineralogy, drilling boreholes and remote sensing techniques . Numerical modeling Forward modeling to: reproduce a specific observation produce basic fluid dynamics Basic fluid dynamics modelling can further be subdivided into instantaneous studies , which aim to reproduce the instantaneous flow in a system due to a given buoyancy distribution, and time-dependent studies , which either aim to reproduce a possible evolution of a given initial condition over time or a statistical (quasi) steady-state of a given system. Basic SI unit & typical constants density: 3000; 2700; 1000 tectonic stress: 10 Mpa (1 pa = 1 N/m2; 1 Mpa = 1e6 pa; 1 Mpa = 10 bar) Young's Modulus for typical rocks: 70 Gpa magnitude for strain in the lithosphere: 1e-4 Possion's ratio: \(\nu=0.25\) heat flux: a flow of energy per unit of area per unit of time. 65 +- 1.6 mWm-2 for continent; 101 +- 2.2 mWm-1 for ocean thermal conductivity k: a measure of its ability to conduct heat. Wm-1K-1 heat capacity: the amount of heat to be supplied to an object to produce a unit change in its temperature. A picture of Geodynamics (Layer cake or plum pudding ?)

Basalt: a fine-grained extrusive igneous rock formed from the rapid cooling of low-viscosity lava rich in magnesium and iron (i.e. Mg & Fe, mafic lava) exposed at or very near the surface of a rocky planet or a mooon. OIB: ocean island basalts (i.e. hotspots in the ocean, due to mantle plume ) Granite (花岗岩): a coarse-grained igneous rock composed mostly of quartz, alkali feldspar (钾长石), and plagioclase (斜长石). It forms from magma with a high content of silica and alkali metal oxides that slowly cools and solidifies underground. It is common in the Earth's continental crust, where it is found in various kinds of igneous intrusions. These range in size from dykes only a few inches across to batholiths exposed over hundreds of square kilometers. It has density of 2.7 g/cm3, and 30-50 km thick. Internal heat budget: The flow of heat from Earth's interior to the surface comes from two main sources in roughly equal amounts: the radiogenic heat produced by the radioactive decay of isotopes in the mantle and crust, and the primordial heat left over from the formation of Earth. Adiabatic expansion (or compression): it causes a drop in temperature. See compression melting for comparison.
